title: ‘This is just the beginning’: Dr Sarah Ruggins on smashing the JOGLEJOG record and what’s next
content:

‘This is just the beginning’: Dr Sarah Ruggins on smashing the JOGLEJOG record and what’s next

Dr Sarah Ruggins smashed the JOGLEJOG there and back record, cycling from John o’ Groats to Land’s End and back again in 5 days, 11 hours, and 14 minutes.

Hailing from Canada but based in Gloucestershire, Ruggins began her record attempt on the 11th May and finished on the 16th May, having ridden over 2,700 kilometres with 18,000 metres of elevation.

The 37-year-old, who we also spoke to before the attempt, beat the men’s record by 6 hours 43 minutes, which was previously held by James MacDonald, and the women’s record by 4 days 17 hours 40 minutes which was held by Louise Harris.

She also raised over £18,000 for the Bike Project and Bikes for Refugees, two charities that help alleviate transportation poverty in England and Scotland.

Throughout the journey, Ruggins had to overcome multiple challenges, including road closures, saddle sores, sleep deprivation, mouth ulcers and the sheer physical and mental toll of riding that distance.

What makes her accomplishment especially remarkable is that Ruggins suffered from a rare and debilitating autoimmune disease as a teenager and only began riding bikes just over two years ago.

‘I’m grateful for believing in myself and I’m grateful for this concept I’ve embedded in my life that I refer to as aggressive patience,’ she says.

‘You might not know where you’re headed, things might seem really difficult, but what you need to focus on is small improvements every day. One step at a time, one day at a time is all you need to know.’

Meditative focus

The first leg down to Land’s End went smoothly. Ruggins said she felt good and even afforded herself 30 seconds to turn around and head back towards John o’ Groats.

To help her push through any challenges she had three words taped to her handlebars: focus, discipline and gratitude.

‘Focus on what you can control,’ she says. ‘I wasn’t looking at distance travelled or where I was in the country, I was looking at my watts and my heart rate and that helped me block out everything else and achieve this meditative focus.

‘I also wanted to remind myself that I was so privileged to be able to do this.’

For most of the ride, Ruggins didn’t know where she was compared to the record she was chasing.

‘I didn’t want to know until near the end of day four when I started having a really hard time. Then my crew started telling me where I was versus the record as a way to draw me out of the suffering I was experiencing.’

Riding through sleep deprivation

Ruggins had to overcome challenges like no longer tolerating solid food and suffering with mouth sores because of having to constantly eat with the aim of taking on 11,000 calories a day.

But the hardest challenge was the sleep deprivation, which set in by the fourth day. Throughout the entire record Sarah had just eight hours sleep.

Her strategy was four hours on the bike, ten minutes off the bike, and the first two days she had an hour and a half of sleep per night. This was then reduced to 15-minute catnaps on the third night, but this pushed things as by day four she was getting confused.

‘It was like nothing I’ve ever experienced before,’ she says. ‘I didn’t know why I was riding a bike, I didn’t know where I was and I was thinking I’ve ridden this road, I’m riding it in circles, I don’t understand what I’m doing.’

At one point she even forgot how to shift her gears and had the mechanic in her ear telling her what to do.

Thanks to her crew who reassured her and guided her through an earpiece, Ruggins eventually came through it.

‘I felt calm because I trusted every single one of my crew members to make decisions on my behalf,’ she says. ‘It just goes to show that while these records are technically solo, there’s nothing solo about it.’

When the sleep deprivation set in, she didn’t just lose her sense of direction but also became hard on herself.

‘I’m a perfectionist and the first three days went so well,’ she says. ‘When I started really struggling from sleep deprivation and those signs started to show up, I felt like I had failed in some way.

‘But my crew was reminding me that this was part of the process and this was coming the entire time, and that was my time to hand over my decision making to my crew and let them guide me the rest of the way.’

Reaching the finish line

By the end of the 2,700km, Ruggins could no longer get off the bike unassisted, so the crew would catch her and help her get off.

As she rolled up to the finish line – the exact same place she had set off from 5 days 11 hours and 14 minutes before – so too did the emotions of what she had achieved.  

‘It was just this feeling of complete release, and that I could rest now and that I was safe and surrounded by my crew,’ she says.

‘The crew leaned me against the post because I was quite unsteady on my feet and I remember just thinking that I did exactly what I said I was going to do and all the stars aligned. I just collapsed and sobbed.’

Endless support

Throughout her ride, Ruggins was greeted by dotwatchers who cheered her on from the roadside and she had two support vans alongside her for most of the time, plus a photographer and a film team.

Leading the support crew was Ryan Clamp, Ruggins’s partner, who is a Royal Marine and Transcontinental Race finisher himself – the pair met at last year’s race.

‘Ryan had an incredibly difficult job of having to keep us to pace and force me to do things that I didn’t want to do when I was in a really fragile state,’ says Ruggins.

‘As we said before the event though, I wouldn’t thank him and the crew if they took it easy on me and we failed the record.’

For Clamp, being so strict and cutthroat with both the crew and Ruggins was tough, but it was seeing her suffering with hypoglycaemia and sleep deprivation that was the most challenging.

‘I said to the crew over and over again, she’s not going to thank you for being kind, she’ll thank you for the results at the end,’ he says.

‘I wasn’t allowed to give Sarah even an extra minute on her breaks, I was there for her to deliver results.

‘The sleep deprivation was quite jarring, one moment she was chatting away happily and then was borderline unconscious when she stopped.

‘I’d warned the team about sleep deprivation but nothing can compare you for the raw chaos and helplessness of the person suffering with it, and how ruthless it is to send that person back out on the bike.

‘The hardest moment was when she went down with hypoglycaemia north of Edinburgh. We got her off the bike and put her in bed, did a first aid assessment, got some glucose and caffeine in her and monitored her. It was an incredibly humbling experience.’

This is just the beginning

Even a few days after beating the record, Ruggins’s ruthless determination and desire to push her limits is evident.

While her sleep pattern hasn’t returned and she’s still getting in some catnaps, she’s already looking forward to the next challenge.

‘This is just the beginning,’ she says. ‘I think I’ve found my limits in the context of this event but what it’s really shown me is like with the right crew and the right community, you can do anything.

‘My coach and I are going to sit down and talk about some opportunities which could fit my skillset.’

This is the bike Ruggins rode to break the record

Ruggins rode a Liv EnviLiv Advanced Pro 0 AXS for the record with 48/35 chainrings and a 10-36 cassette.

‘We chose it to get every aero advantage we could whilst maintaining comfort for her over such a sustained effort,’ says Pete Alfano, head mechanic of the record attempt and founder of Alfano Frameworks.

‘The clip-on tri bar kit from Liv was particularly useful, plus the Aerocoach armrests, which were gifted to us by a friend and provided a really good stable base for her. 

‘The Restrap race top-tube bag was an essential for giving Sarah super-easy access to her snacks and proper sports nutrition on the road.

‘She also used Exposure lights for front and back visibility plus white reflective tape strips on the bike for added visibility at night.’

The numbers

  • 18,000 metres climbed
  • 2,700km ridden
  • 300 Precision Hydration chews consumed
  • 15 Huel shakes a day
  • 8 hours of sleep
  • 0 mechanicals
